title: Bank Terminologies
introduction: Understanding common banking terms and detailed financial terminologies is essential for effective communication in the financial services industry. This module covers account types, common banking terms, and a comprehensive list of abbreviations and their explanations.

content.value: Banks offer various types of accounts to meet different customer needs and financial goals.
Savings Account
A basic deposit account that earns interest, designed for saving money rather than frequent transactions.
Current Account
A transaction account primarily used by businesses and individuals who need to make frequent withdrawals and deposits.
Fixed Deposit Account
An account where money is deposited for a fixed period at a predetermined interest rate.
Recurring Deposit Account
An account that allows regular deposits of a fixed amount for a specified period, earning interest at rates similar to fixed deposits.
These terms are frequently used in day-to-day banking operations and customer interactions.
CASA
Current Account Savings Account ratio, representing the proportion of total deposits that are held in current and savings accounts.
KYC
Know Your Customer, the process of verifying the identity and address of customers to prevent fraud and money laundering.
NEFT
National Electronic Funds Transfer, a payment system facilitating one-to-one funds transfers between bank accounts.
RTGS
Real Time Gross Settlement, a system where funds transfer takes place in real time between banks.
IMPS
Immediate Payment Service, an instant interbank electronic fund transfer service available 24/7.
Key Abbreviations

items: CIBIL – Credit Information Bureau India Limited

content.value: Detailed Explanations

Additional key terms include: 'Repo rate'—the rate at which RBI lends to commercial banks; 'Liquidity'—the ease of converting assets into cash; 'Variable rate'—an interest rate that fluctuates with market conditions; and 'Prepayment'—paying off a part of the loan early to reduce interest. These explanations help clarify how each term impacts banking operations and customer transactions.
